ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course provided a good introduction to self-published words and different methods of printing, such as riso printing.
Risograph printing, photoshop, critique etiquette, history and current practices of self publishing.
A lot of freedom to experiment with what we wanted to make. Learned how to use the risograph l, bind books, make clam shell boxes, and zines.
I learned how to use the riso printer, and how to do color separations and various printing techniques!
I learned specifically about risograph printing and the small/independent publishing world at large.
Became more familiar with different forms of artist books and bookmaking practices. Gained hands-on experience with zine-making.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course involved a lot of fun, hands-on activities such as drawing, printing, and book making! It is a great course for anyone looking for an engaging yet relaxed studio environment. I felt that due to the set up of the course, such as our scheduled collection visits and guest lecturers, I didn't produce as much as I would've liked, but the projects I did complete were worth while.

I really enjoyed the studio days and how collaborative this class was, I was able to gain a great technical skill set with risograph printing and photoshop, and classmates were always ready to help thanks to our collaborative projects.

Strengths: a lot of materials to use, free to use the risograph, a very open and relaxed environment 

I think perhaps more direction on mixing colours on the Riso would be great.
I loved the community that developed in this class. However, there wasn't a lot of clear and direct instruction or guidance on how to do various techniquesstudents very much helped each other out.
The class is extremely interesting and the class critiques are very helpful. However, I wish we had learned a larger range of techniques in publishing.

Strengths: Enthusiastic instructor. Engaged group of students. Print shop environment is conducive to in-class work. 

Weaknesses: Bit of a lack of structure. Not as much printmaking practice as I expectedeach assignment was risograph-based, which I was surprised by (I don't think this was clearly stated in the syllabus). Zine-heavy, which is fine but also not entirely expected.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would highly recommend this course to any student looking for an approachable studio art course. I felt that the class environment was always welcoming and engaging, and that every idea was encouraged and pushed further.

Absolutely, this art class included relevant conversations with guest lecturers, museum visits, and insight about current self publishing practices, yet had plenty of time to work on projects in class
Yes! There's a lot of room and celebration of experimentation. If you're interested in illustration, poetry, photography, making comics, etc., zine making is a great way to showcase those interests.
Yes, I think it lets you explore a lot of different ways you want to create.

I would recommend it if you already have your own printmaking practice and want a wonderful space to make work in! I would not recommend to an absolute beginnerthere's a lot of prior knowledge assumed in the course.
I would recommend this class to a student interested in zine publishing, riso-printing, and editioning.
